body:
> This seems quite odd. I would have thought [3, 0] would have made more sense, i.e. window size of 3 starting at the current value (0).

Yes, agreed!!

I have had long discussions with @danbartl about this, and he was adamant about that *you* suggested the convention that leads to the "-1", so he changed it from the "better" encoding to what it currently is. This is quite funny ðŸ˜† since your comment confirms it must has been some kind of miscommunication (because you don't actually seem to think that??). 

Anyway, we have jointly agreed that we will change it to "0 lag means output = input time series", which also seems to be your favoured option, and that the current situation has the status of a bug because there is such a strong user expectation.
Unfortunately, @danbartl is off sick, so the fix might not make it into 0.11.0.
(the work is being carried out in this PR https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2154)

Thanks @fkiraly . Yes, it might have been miscommunicated/misinterpreted. But I am glad that the change is happening now. 

Just so we avoid miscommunication again, could you clarify what you mean by the following. I am not sure I follow that.

> "0 lag means output = input time series"
@fkiraly Also, would this change apply to "Observation 2" as well (for lags) or only for functions like "mean", "median", etc.?

@ngupta23, regarding observation 1: this is one of those things where you get more confused the more you look at it...
If you had the time, I would much appreciate if you could look into the docstring of the PR
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2154/files
and check whether the indexing is now "right" in your opinion. And/or play around with it.
(to me it looks like the fix is already in, but @danbartl didn't give a heads-up because he went off sick)

Re observation 2, indeed, we've discussed that it should be easier to pass lags, without the `window_length` number. I'm not sure whether that's already included in #2154 though.

issue.title: [ENH] WindowSummarizer to deal with hierarchical data

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Hierarchical datatype can use WindowSummarizer  efficiently with groupy operations. This PR includes some fixes to conform with new hierarchical data format. 

This is part of a larger preparation of changes for the upcoming hierarchical / panel use case

You can see a working example here:

https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2074

Reference Issues/PRs
see above

Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?
No.

What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?
Any other comments?
PR checklist
For all contributions
[x ] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
For new estimators

body:
@fkiraly I think it is still not consistent with what is proposed in this issue

https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2154/files#r835367534
@danbartl, appreciate your eyes on this once you are back...
